item.title: Best of San Telmo Street Art
item.dc:creator: razalba
item.description: San Telmo, the oldest barrio in Buenos Aires, is known for antique stores, milongas, cobblestone streets, traditional cafés and old school parrillas.  A barrio where the retro-cool hardcore kids live in their high ceiling, historic apartments.  My favorite thing about San Telmo? It houses some of the best street art in the city.  Ditch the crowded [...]
item.content:encoded: San Telmo, the oldest barrio in Buenos Aires, is known for antique stores, milongas, cobblestone streets, traditional cafés and old school parrillas.  A barrio where the retro-cool hardcore kids live in their high ceiling, historic apartments.  My favorite thing about San Telmo? It houses some of the best street art in the city.  Ditch the crowded San Telmo Feria, flocking around the B-level Tango street performers, and check out the great street art.  Here are some of my faves….

item.title: I should probably buy a new toothbrush
item.dc:creator: katiefoutz
item.description: The bathroom. Ben pauses while brushing his teeth to tell Mama something. Whether it’s a confession or a threat, she’s not sure.   Ben: “I throw Jonah’s toothbrush in the toilet? He will get a new one.” Mama: “Wait. What?” (She sees Jonah’s toothbrush is still in its holder.) “When did you do that?” Ben: [...]
item.content:encoded:
SURE, trouble just finds you.

The bathroom. Ben pauses while brushing his teeth to tell Mama something. Whether it’s a confession or a threat, she’s not sure.

 

Ben: “I throw Jonah’s toothbrush in the toilet? He will get a new one.”

Mama: “Wait. What?” (She sees Jonah’s toothbrush is still in its holder.) “When did you do that?”

Ben: “Because he will get a new one.”

Mama: “No, WHEN?”

Ben: “Because he will get a new one.”

Mama: “He’ll get a new one when it’s time to get a new one. Please don’t throw his toothbrush in the toilet. That’s yucky. OK?”

Ben: “OK …”

item.title: Snowmaggedon? No, just a January veggie-lanche
item.dc:creator: caligirl
item.description: More California goodness. Garden harvest in January! We planted container gardens at our old place wayyyyyy back in August. We finally have some gorgeous vegetable goodness, in the dead of winter. Carrots and beets, they’re small, but delicious! Can’t wait for the second (and cross your fingers for a third) round. Delish. The harvest! Yes, [...]
item.content:encoded:
More California goodness. Garden harvest in January! We planted container gardens at our old place wayyyyyy back in August. We finally have some gorgeous vegetable goodness, in the dead of winter. Carrots and beets, they’re small, but delicious! Can’t wait for the second (and cross your fingers for a third) round. Delish.

The harvest! Yes, only two beets, but if those weren’t the most delicious beets in the world …

Are you ready for your close ups little veggies? I thought you were.

Me holding my loot. Not bad for a January weekend.

For me, garden fresh veggies don’t need much improvement by way of the kitchen. We usually just scrub them well, cut larger pieces in half and remove the greens for salad, then toss them in a bit of olive oil, salt, pepper, and, if we’re feeling really ambitious, garlic, and then stick them in a oven at 375 for 20 – 30 minutes. No fancy cooking skills needed!

We paired  this with BBQ Pork Spare Ribs from Riverdog Farms (part of Kirk’s Christmas present) my souped-up Jiffy corn muffins, and a salad of carrot greens, salad mix, strawberries and goat cheese. Fairly impressed on this “what’s in the fridge (and the garden)?” day.

item.title: Brief Job Interview with Hideous Man
item.dc:creator: Pizza Cottontail
item.description: I have a job interview today! I don’t sleep well the night before the interview. I obsess about all the questions they’ll ask and fine-tune my answers. But all night I concoct out-of-the-blue questions they could spring on me, like: “I spotted two typos on your résumé. Were they intentional?” or “Can you explain how [...]
item.content:encoded:
I have a job interview today!

I don’t sleep well the night before the interview. I obsess about all the questions they’ll ask and fine-tune my answers. But all night I concoct out-of-the-blue questions they could spring on me, like: “I spotted two typos on your résumé. Were they intentional?” or “Can you explain how you got a C in your college introductory-level film class?” or “If you were a Norse god, which one would you be?” By the time my alarm goes off, I’ve slept a total of maybe ten minutes, and I’ve decided that my Norse god is definitely Brighid, but then I’m not sure if Brighid is a god or a goddess. Or Norse or Celtic, for that matter. All that preparation for nothing!

After the interview, the second-guessing begins: I kick myself for forgetting to tell the story about how I saved everyone when my house almost burned down, and I fret over whether the interviewer thought I was flirting when I said I was a team player. And then I don’t sleep until I hear whether I got the job.

I’ll purge my pre-interview jitters by sharing the interview questions I dread the most:

Tell us a little about yourself. Always the first question, always the worst. It’s so open-ended. Do you want me to re-hash my résumé? Explain why I’m qualified for the job? Wax poetic about my family life? Recall an anecdote about my Midwestern adolescence? Reveal my most embarrassing moment? Expound on my hopes and dreams and fears? Justify my Super Bowl pick? Argue convincingly that Patrick Swayze was the most important role model for Generation X? Bemoan contemporary fiction’s overuse of shock and meta-fictional techniques? I’m an open book! Just tell me what you want to hear!

How did you get along with your last boss? I know that interviewers ask this question to gauge how well you respond to authority, so I’m supposed to answer, “My last boss was the best. Except for you, I’m sure.” But it’s going to take a great effort to keep quiet about my last boss’s proclivity for emoticons in work e-mails.

What’s your biggest strength? True story: I hadn’t prepared for my first post-college job interview at all (unless you count staying sober the night before), so this question took my by surprise. I think I stammered out something like, “I’m, um…confident?”

What’s your biggest weakness? You only want one?

Do you have any questions for us? The most pressing question for me is whether the staff restrooms are nice. I don’t like it when they have one private restroom for staff–what if the person before me made a stink, and I go in just to wash my hands, and when I open the door I discover the boss is next in line? That won’t do, but I haven’t found a way to casually ask an interviewer.

What about you, reader? What’s your least favorite job interview question?

(Photo from Library of Congress on Flickr Commons)

item.title: Which Cities Are The Most Generous?
item.dc:creator: danariely
item.description: Recently I decided to come up with a rough measure of generosity across different communities. Which communities have a culture of giving away unused items as opposed to trying to sell them? And why? One of the ideas was to use Craigslist as a rough measure. Looking at the 23 major cities on Craigslist, we [...]
item.content:encoded:
Recently I decided to come up with a rough measure of generosity across different communities. Which communities have a culture of giving away unused items as opposed to trying to sell them? And why?

One of the ideas was to use Craigslist as a rough measure. Looking at the 23 major cities on Craigslist, we took the number of free items being given away in one week and divided it by the number of items being sold in the furniture category, as a quick index of generosity. In a nutshell: for every 100 items of furniture being sold, how many items are being given away for free?


As you can see, Portland, SF Bay, Boston, and Seattle come up on top in terms of this measurement, with Miami, Phoenix, and Houston on the bottom.

Is this a good metric for measuring generosity across communities?

item.title: 2011 – Will Social TV Live Up To The Hype?
item.dc:creator: quepasablog
item.description: This time last year we began a research and development project on social TV for one of our media clients. It was apparent then that social TV had begun to significantly change the way that consumers were watching television – and increasingly seeking out access to engaging and socialised experiences in all areas of media [...]
item.content:encoded:
Million Pound Drop - 2nd screen

This time last year we began a research and development project on social TV for one of our media clients. It was apparent then that social TV had begun to significantly change the way that consumers were watching television – and increasingly seeking out access to engaging and socialised experiences in all areas of media consumption. The second screen (whether laptop or mobile) was being increasingly used – with Twitter and other social networks – as an accompaniment to TV viewing.

In response, broadcasters, content providers and digital start-ups rapidly became interested in how this new space could offer fresh opportunities to enhance viewer experience, driving interactivity, community and talkability around programme brands.

We identified the appearance of three basic types of contenders: convergent TV services (YouView, Google TV and Verizon FiOS in the US), dedicated devices and technologies (Boxee, Popbox, Roku) and social TV applications online or on mobile (Tunerfish, Miso, Philo).

In the UK, perhaps the most prominent development in recent months has been the advent of live ‘playalong’ scenarios on the web, for example Monterosa’s work on Million Pound Drop (C4) and America’s Next Top Model (Living).

With the continued growth and diversification of web and mobile applications and integration of social networking into all aspects of our lives, 2011 is being predicted to be the year of social TV. Large media firms and broadcasters cannot afford to get left behind in the race to establish a sound (and preferably revenue-driving) business model, and new start-ups seem to be appearing every day.

Most are in the US and many remain in beta testing: Tunerfish, Starling, Miso, Philo, Yap.TV, and perhaps 2011 newcomer Into_Now. GetGlue has been around longer – since 2007 – and offers a broader proposition of entertainment ‘check-ins’ (TV, movies, music, books) which saw its user base grow from 30,000 to over 650,000 in 2010.

But it’s very much anybody’s game at this point. Features like check-ins, points/badge systems, real-time chat, voting, social network integration and exclusive content are being offered, but it will be the users/viewers that decide what type of social TV experience they prefer. Ultimately, second screen social content must add to, not distract from, the TV viewing experience. This added value must also be meaningfully extended to advertisers and sponsors on whose support these social platforms depend.

item.title: How To: Teach Sawing to a Young Student
item.dc:creator: woodshopcowboy
item.description: I have a perfect record in the woodshop.  No fatalities. I have had two injuries though this year (I average about one a quarter or semester).  Both happened due to good sawing habits gone bad. This picture shows my basic hand-saw set up when I cut a board to size.  I’m right-handed and for south-pawed students, [...]
item.content:encoded:
I have a perfect record in the woodshop.  No fatalities.

I have had two injuries though this year (I average about one a quarter or semester).  Both happened due to good sawing habits gone bad.

This picture shows my basic hand-saw set up when I cut a board to size.  I’m right-handed and for south-pawed students, I mirror the set up.
I would saw about an inch from the edge of the table.  Notice I use a bench hook to keep slips/movement to a minimum and pinch my thumb in so I don’t catch it on a saw (though I’m lazy with that index finger!).  I have the kids put their weight into their left hand to steady the workpiece.  I generally build the workbenches 30″-32″ high to accommodate younger statures.  I’ve never had a student cut themselves after setting themselves up like this, righty or lefty.

Trouble is, sometimes that’s not the most accessible way to hand-saw a board.  Small pieces for example, or a face-vise set-up in the left side of a bench like this necessitate a different technique:

Now pretend you’re a student.  You go to make this cut (a rip down the pencil mark) and the board naturally wiggles.  Remember how I teach to use the left hand to steady the work?  Well, my student’s see my “good” habits and this is their solution:

And so, midway through the cut, this happens:

And there goes the finger! Nurse! Nurse! We got a bleeder!

Both finger injuries have happened in this manner – a cut at the end of wood when the lumber is chucked/clamped down on the student’s strong-hand side.  I researched a bit and I’ve seen two ways to avoid this from happening.  One hand behind the back,

or the two-handed approach.

The one-handed technique is great for students to gain a “feel” for cutting the wood correctly.  A saw should glide through the wood with minimal downward pressure for the user – the saw does the work.  Long strokes produce cleaner and faster cuts than short strokes.  Move your body so your arm swings in a straight line in the direction of the cut (similar to a proper stroke of a pool cue actually).  I will (once I re-teach the safe way to saw during this cut!) ask the kids to try a one-handed approach to reinforce proper technique.  Then the students will  switch to a two-handed approach to gain speed.  Also, remember to teach how to re-adjust the placing of wood in the vise to minimize board movement, the original reason the second hand got involved in the first place.

So, a few things to remember when teaching woodworking to young students:

  • Different cuts, different set-ups must be taught as separate units.  Young people don’t gain adult-like abstraction skills until fifteen or so.  Young people’s brains haven’t developed those brain cells yet.  If you change the pattern, you must re-teach the technique.
  • Watch yourself first because monkey see, monkey do.  In this case, my habits in one environment (and the habits I ingrained in my students) did not translate to a successful skill when the situation changed.  Look at your habits and think about how those habits might affect the students’ thought patterns.
  • Re-evaluate and research your own skills – this is why I blog here, why I’m working on a Master’s in Ed, why I play in the woodshop on the weekends.  I can’t expect my students to be satisfied with the projects and level of production I see now.  I must plan for the future and improve my teaching toolkit.

Two sites which enlightened me on my quest to solve the sawed finger mystery:  http://woodworking-kids.com/ & Doug Stowe’s Wisdom of the Hands.

media:content.media:title: What Every Woodshop Teacher Must Do Once
Mental Trick to Get Around It

item.title: Through the Mist…
item.dc:creator: eyevindicate
item.description: I went to bed early last night so I could be up early to go out and take some pictures. I figured with the weather we have been having, I should make use of being finished with work. As always I awoke this morning to find that the good weather was gone, and instead had [...]
item.content:encoded:
I went to bed early last night so I could be up early to go out and take some pictures. I figured with the weather we have been having, I should make use of being finished with work. As always I awoke this morning to find that the good weather was gone, and instead had been replaced with clouds and heavy fog. At first I thought damn, but after waking up some more and looking out the window more thoroughly, I realized I might actually be able to get some awesome pictures. So I went out after all.

It’s amazing what you can see when you can’t see everything. When the fog limits the viewing distance the things you look right through on a daily basis are suddenly forced into sight. I found it very peaceful being out there, lost in the never-ending mist. I’ve always heard of fog being creepy and eerie, at least that’s how it’s portrayed in movies, but this was really peaceful. Would love to be able to photograph in the fog at night. I bet the lights would look awesome in the fog.

item.title: After a taste of Tina Fey’s prose in ‘The New Yorker’, we want more!

Her writing here isn’t quite what you’d expect of a typical comedian’s book—there [...]

item.title: Just Like Old Times?
item.dc:creator: The Hip Flask
item.description: A Three Part Lamentation on Modern Drinking Culture Part 1: Progress? The idea of progress and drinking has been on my mind lately.  New drink creations, new styles of decor, and re-imaginations of old classics seem to be all the rage.  New technology follows these new trends, be it bars that pitch their Wi-Fi hotspots [...]
item.content:encoded:
A Three Part Lamentation on Modern Drinking Culture

Part 1: Progress?

The idea of progress and drinking has been on my mind lately.  New drink creations, new styles of decor, and re-imaginations of old classics seem to be all the rage.  New technology follows these new trends, be it bars that pitch their Wi-Fi hotspots or boast of countless high-definition televisions.  These technologies have become ubiquitous in bars and pubs, which has made finding a place to quietly enjoy a drink or two away from the noise and bustle of daily life increasingly difficult.

Drinking culture has regressed much since the 1940s and 50s.  Since then the omnipresence of jukeboxes, televisions, and cell phones have all but destroyed bar culture, where once only the din of conversation filled the air.  Noisy, crowded, television-filled mega-bars are fine if you are looking for such a place; if you aren’t, your are likely to find that your options are disappointingly limited.  The modern pace and ambiance – the culture of drink itself – is dramatically different.

Yet have these changes bettered drinking?  What happened to traditional drinking culture, when a man could hang his hat and loosen his tie, order a whisky, and recess into dimly lit booths to conspire and commiserate beneath the background murmur of intimate conversations?


Filed under: Miscellaneous Tagged: Cocktails, Culture
